For any <math display="inline">\vec{v}, \vec{u} \in \mathbb{R} ^{n}</math> we have <math display="block">\left| \vec{v}  \cdot  \vec{u} \right| \le \left\Vert \vec{v} \right\Vert \left\Vert \vec{u} \right\Vert</math>

== Proof ==

* We start by using the algebraic definition of <math>\alpha </math> to obtain an equivalent statements using <math>\gamma</math>, since <math>\sqrt{ \left( \vec{v}  \cdot \vec{u} \right) ^{2}} , \left\Vert \vec{v} \right\Vert \left\Vert \vec{u} \right\Vert \in [0, \infty)</math>
<math display="block">\begin{aligned}
  \sqrt{ \left( \vec{v}  \cdot \vec{u} \right) ^{2}} \le \left\Vert \vec{v} \right\Vert \left\Vert \vec{u} \right\Vert &\Rightarrow \left( \vec{v}  \cdot  \vec{u} \right) ^{2} \le \left( \left\Vert \vec{v} \right\Vert \left\Vert \vec{u} \right\Vert \right) ^{2}\\\end{aligned}</math>

* It follows directly from the geometric definition of <math>\beta</math>, we have
<math display="block">\vec{v}  \cdot  \vec{u} \stackrel{\mathtt{D}}{=} \left\Vert v \right\Vert \left\Vert u \right\Vert \cos  \left( \theta \right) </math>

* Then 
<math display="block">\left( \vec{v}  \cdot  \vec{u} \right) ^{2} =   \left(  \left\Vert v \right\Vert \left\Vert u \right\Vert \cos  \left( \theta \right) \right) ^{2}</math>

* We recall that <math display="inline">-1 \le \cos  \left( \theta \right) \le 1</math> therefore <math display="inline">0 \le \cos  \left( \theta \right) ^{2} \le 1</math> thus we have 
<math display="block">\left( \vec{v}   \cdot \vec{u} \right) ^{2} = \left( \left\Vert v \right\Vert \left\Vert u \right\Vert \right) ^{2} \cos  \left( \theta \right) ^{2 } \le \left( \left\Vert \vec{v} \right\Vert \left\Vert \vec{u} \right\Vert \right) ^{2}  \cdot 1</math>

* In other words, we've just obtained that 
<math display="block">\left( \vec{v}  \cdot  \vec{u} \right) ^{2} \le \left( \left\Vert \vec{v}  \right\Vert \left\Vert \vec{u} \right\Vert \right) ^{2}</math>

* So we have the result
